data.title: Sara Soueidan
data.content: [Sara Soueidan](https://www.sarasoueidan.com/blog/) - Read/Subscribe - Sara has written some great articles on writing semantic and accessible HTML. She's also an all-round great human.

data.title: Metatags.io
data.content: [Metatags.io](https://metatags.io/) - Social Share Preview - A handy little tool to preview how your blog posts and site links will look when shared on different platforms.

data.title: Colorable
data.content: [Colorable](https://colorable.jxnblk.com/) - Contrast Checker - An easy to understand colour contrast checker by Brent Jackson.

data.title: Where to put Buttons in Forms
data.content: [Where to put Buttons in Forms](https://adamsilver.io/articles/where-to-put-buttons-in-forms/) - Read - Full of some great tips for making your forms easy on the eye, understandable and functional. You may see some of these as common sense but it's always good to have those references for particular use cases.

data.title: HTML5 Hidden Attribute
data.content: [HTML5 Hidden Attribute](https://davidwalsh.name/html5-hidden) - Read - Why use CSS when HTML can do all of the heavy lifting for you? A short article on using the hidden attribute and making your HTML that smidgen more semantic.

data.title: @argyleink
data.content: [@argyleink](https://twitter.com/argyleink) - Follow/Read - Adam Argyle is a great follow on twitter for anyone interested in CSS snippets, topping up your general knowledge and seeing what's on the horizon and being added to browsers.

data.title: Animation Performance
data.content: [Animation Performance](https://motion.dev/guides/performance) - Read/Guide - A solid animation guide from Matt Perry ([@mattgperry](https://twitter.com/mattgperry?s=21)). Useful to anyone regardless of whether you’re using [Motion One](https://motion.dev) or not.

data.title: Everything I Learned About min(), max(), clamp() In CSS
data.content: [Everything I Learned About min(), max(), clamp() In CSS](https://ishadeed.com/article/css-min-max-clamp/) - Read - Ahmed has wrote a great post for those wanting to familiarize themselves with min(), max() and clamp() CSS functions. I'm excited for this addition to the language and it will revolutionize responsive declarations.

data.title: Dense Discovery
data.content: [Dense Discovery](https://www.densediscovery.com/) - Inspirational/Critical Thinking - I look forward to [@KaiBrach](https://twitter.com/kaibrach)'s newsletter each week and it never fails to inspire or have some sort of impression on my day. Well worth a subscribe.

data.title: Spotify Design
data.content: [Spotify Design](https://spotify.design/) - Product Design - These guys write some great articles about product design. They also have some playlists you can listen to whilst designing (which is always a bonus).

data.title: Sidebar
data.content: [Sidebar](https://sidebar.io/) - 5 links a day - A long time favourite of mine and Sidebar never scuppers on sending quality content. I'll admit sometimes 5 links can be a little overwhelming to check daily in that case I recommend just going on the site every now and then, you won't be disappointed.

data.title: Staff Design
data.content: [Staff Design](https://staff.design/) - The Individual Contributor Path - I'm a massive fan of anything Brian Lovin does and this is no exception. Brian interviews a great collection of designers and gets some great insights into career growth and the Individual Contributor Path.

data.title: Lovers Magazine
data.content: [Lovers Magazine](https://www.loversmagazine.com/) - Essential Designer Questions - Previously Interface Lovers, Lovers Magazine amplifies the voice of the designer. Asking the essential questions every designer wants to know in order to push and inspire themselves and creatives in the community.

data.title: Savee
data.content: [Savee](https://savee.it/) - Collect Inspiration - Like Pinterest but much MUCH better. The content you can source and stumble upon here is much better quality than pretty much anything out there. It's better for graphic design but all inspiration is good inspiration, right?

data.title: Figma
data.content: [Figma](https://www.figma.com/) - Collaboration/Design - In my opinion THE best design tool out there right now. Collaborate with other designer friends, work up prototypes for design sprints and share your work easily with developers. It's pretty much a life saver!

data.title: Erase.bg
data.content: [Erase.bg](https://www.erase.bg/en/) - AI Background Removal - Need to remove the background from an image but don't have the time to open Photoshop and do it by hand? [Erase.bg](https://www.erase.bg/en/) makes it super easy and it’s free with a generous 5000x5000 resolution limit.

data.title: Space, Grids and Layouts
data.content: [Space, Grids, and Layouts](https://www.designsystems.com/space-grids-and-layouts/) - Design Systems - My go-to article when thinking about layouts and initial setup. A huge helper in defining spacing and starting to understand the fundamentals.

data.title: A Complete Guide to Typography
data.content: [A Complete Guide to Typography](https://www.designsystems.com/iconography-guide/) - Design Systems - Essential reading when starting on your iconography journey. Again getting that initial setup makes all the difference in making your icons consistent and beautiful to look at.

data.title: Icons & Keylines Demystified
data.content: [Icons & Keylines Demystified](https://medium.com/@minoraxis/icon-grids-keylines-demystified-5a228fe08cfd) - Icon Design - A great introduction to the different approaches you can take to your guide setup to create consistent icons. I tend to go for the Material design approach but it's whatever works for you.

data.title: Icon Sets
data.content:
- [Radix Icons](https://icons.modulz.app/)
- [CSS.gg Icon Set](https://css.gg/)
- [Feather Icons](https://feathericons.com/)
- [Remix Icons](https://remixicon.com/)
- [Teeny Icons](https://teenyicons.com/)

If you use [UnoCSS](https://github.com/antfu/unocss) (I use it for quite a few of my projects) it has a fantastic feature which let's you add icons via class names. Each icon is pulled from [icones.js.org](https://icones.js.org/), a huge collection of open source icons. Alternatively, if you prefer to use icons as components check out [unplugin-icons](https://github.com/antfu/unplugin-icons) on GitHub.

data.title: Sticky CSS Grid Items
data.content: [Sticky CSS Grid Items](https://melanie-richards.com/blog/css-grid-sticky/) - Read - A great article from [@soMelanieSaid](https://twitter.com/soMelanieSaid) on using position sticky with css grid items. This was reference I used when positioning the sidebar content on this site.

data.title: A Complete Guide to Flexbox
data.content: [A Complete Guide to Flexbox](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/) - Read/Bookmark - The ultimate guide guide to flexbox. CSS tricks nailed this one and it's one of the best and easiest to understand guides out there

data.title: A Complete Guide to Grid
data.content: [A Complete Guide to Grid](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/complete-guide-grid/) - Read/Bookmark - Another great CSS layouts guide from CSS tricks. I find myself referencing this a lot stored some snippets for easy access.

data.title: Smoother & sharper shadows with layered box-shadows
data.content: [Smoother & sharper shadows with layered box-shadows](https://tobiasahlin.com/blog/layered-smooth-box-shadows/) - Read - Create smoother box-shadows with some techniques from Tobias. Philipp Brumm also created this [tool](https://brumm.af/shadows) inspired by the article. One thing I would love is if it created several box-shadow classes with varying sizes and strengths.

data.title: Toptotal
data.content: [Toptotal](https://www.toptal.com/designers/htmlarrows/symbols/) - HTML entities - Find the HTML equivalent to many a symbol, I've used this quite a few times and a good site is pretty hard to find on this!

data.title: Inclusively Hiding & Styling Checkboxes and Radio Buttons
data.content: [Inclusively Hiding & Styling Checkboxes and Radio Buttons](https://www.sarasoueidan.com/blog/inclusively-hiding-and-styling-checkboxes-and-radio-buttons) - Read - Ever wondered how to make your checkboxes and radio buttons accessible? Sara explains the current pitfalls in using just CSS and talks us through an elegant approach that takes advantage of SVG.

data.title: Styling Layout Wrappers In CSS
data.content:
[Styling Layout Wrappers In CSS](https://ishadeed.com/article/styling-wrappers-css) - Read - A comprehensive introduction on creating and styling Layout wrappers. I'm
a big fan of this article because it covers a lot of use cases.

data.title: Curated sites
data.content:
- [Godly Website](https://godly.website/)
- [Admire the Web](https://www.admiretheweb.com/)
- [Best Website Gallery](https://bestwebsite.gallery/)
- [Hover States](https://www.hoverstat.es/)
- [Klikkentheke](https://klikkentheke.com/)
- [Minimal Gallery](https://minimal.gallery/)
- [Site Inspire](https://www.siteinspire.com/)
- [The Gallery](https://thegallery.io/)
- [The Responsive](http://the-responsive.com/)

data.title: Anthony Fu's Personal Site
data.content: [Anthony Fu](https://antfu.me/) - A Project Machine - An incredible talent when it comes to [creating great projects](https://antfu.me/projects) and contributing to the dev community. I honestly don't know how he gets so much done in a day!

data.title: Brian Lovin's Personal Site
data.content: [Brian Lovin](https://brianlovin.com/) - Great Design, Great Content - It should be no surprise that I'm a big fan of Brian's work. In fact there's a lot of elements on his site which have inspired this site. Make sure to checkout his [AMA page](https://brianlovin.com/ama) (it's great).

data.title: Paco Coursey's Personal Site
data.content: [Paco Coursey](https://paco.sh/) - Nav, Transitions and Icons - Paco has done some great work for Vercel and their design system. I can't help but love the focus on using shortcuts and the transitions he uses for his nav menu.

data.title: Jesper Vos' Personal Site
data.content: [Jesper Vos](https://www.jespervos.com/) - Portfolio Site - Jesper's site is one of my favourites to come back too. His projects are exciting, full of interesting interactions and visually beautiful.

data.title: LateNightCheckout
data.content: [LateNightCheckout](https://latecheckout.studio/) - Product Studios - A really interesting idea and something I can see becoming a thing of the future.

data.title: Monopo
data.content: [Monopo](https://monopo.london/) - Digital Design - An exciting studio with some great case studies. They’ve recently redesigned their site and it is looking very good (the interactive gradients and transitions especially)

data.title: Javascript Weekly
data.content: [Javascript Weekly](https://javascriptweekly.com/) - Weekly Round-Up - A free, once-weekly email roundup of latest JavaScript news and articles. There is some great stuff shared each week and gives you a good sense of the community.

data.title: Tania Rascia
data.content: [Tania Rascia](https://www.taniarascia.com/) - No Ads, No Bullshit - [@taniarascia](https://twitter.com/taniarascia) has a real gift for making new and potentially confusing concepts simple and easy to understand. This is an essential subscribe (and check out her backlog).

data.title: Kent C Dodds
data.content: [Kent C Dodds](https://kentcdodds.com/subscribe/) - He's a Wizard Harry - Because it's Kent Dodds... Joking but also not joking. I reference a lot of Kent's articles all of the time so I can guarantee you will find something you like.

data.title: Just Javascript
data.content: [Just Javascript](https://justjavascript.com/) - The Fundamentals - [@dan_abramov](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov) is a legend in the React/Javascript community and to top it off he and Maggie Appleton have created this newsletter course to help you understand the fundamentals at a deeper level.

data.title: Josh Comeau
data.content: [Josh Comeau](https://joshwcomeau.com/) - Site Envy Included - I followed [@JoshWComeau](https://twitter.com/JoshWComeau) before I subscribed to his newsletter and everything he puts out there is great. Highly recommended (and try not to envy his site too much).

data.title: Syntax FM
data.content: [Syntax FM](https://syntax.fm/) - Podcast Royalty - An invaluable podcast hosted by the one and only Wes Bos and Scott Tolinski. I switch up my podcasts a lot but I listen to these guys every week without fail.

data.title: Higher Order Functions
data.content: [Higher Order Functions](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BMUiFMZr7vk&list=PL0zVEGEvSaeEd9hlmCXrk5yUyqUag-n84) - Watch/Playlist - Fun Fun Function is one of my favourite Youtube channels and I have followed him for a while now. Regardless if you are new to JavaScript or been at it a while Matthias is great at explaining daunting topics through simple examples.

data.title: David Walsh Fetch Api
data.content: [David Walsh Fetch Api Article](https://davidwalsh.name/fetch) - Read - An article I come back to time and time again when I spontaneously forget how to use the fetch API (it happens a lot).

data.title: Understanding Map and Set
data.content: [Understanding Map and Set](https://www.taniarascia.com/understanding-map-and-set-javascript/) - Read - [@taniarascia](https://twitter.com/taniarascia) has written a great post on the new iterable objects types introduced in ECMAScript 2015. I'm pretty new to Map and Set so this gave me a good understanding of when it could be used.

data.title: How to Modify Nodes in an Abstract Syntax Tree
data.content: [How to Modify Nodes in an Abstract Syntax Tree](https://css-tricks.com/how-to-modify-nodes-in-an-abstract-syntax-tree/) - Parsing Markdown - If you've ever created a plugin in Gatsby this might be familiar to you. [@jlengstorf](https://twitter.com/jlengstorf) talks us through how to create an AST from markdown and how to manipulate what HTML is output.

data.title: HTML with Superpowers
data.content: [HTML with Superpowers](https://daverupert.com/2021/10/html-with-superpowers/) - Web Components - I found this to be one of the more helpful intros to web components and how useful they could be for the future of web development. As much as I like React I am always an advocate for a simpler web.

data.title: Operator Lookup
data.content: [Operator Lookup](https://www.joshwcomeau.com/operator-lookup/) - Handy JavaScript Operator Lookup - Forget trying to google those peaky operators you've seen on Stackoverflow (you can't by the way, google doesn't like it). Josh Comeau has create a great little tool to help us with just that.

data.title: Bundlephobia
data.content: [Bundlephobia](https://bundlephobia.com/) - NPM module cost - A good sounding board for whether an npm should be installed. If something seems a little large I'll tend to look for something else or build something custom.

data.title: Overreacted by Dan Abramov
data.content: [Overreacted by Dan Abramov](https://overreacted.io/) - Dans just great - A well respected member of the javascript community Dans shares the latest React news, his thoughts and explanations of react concepts.

data.title: React Status
data.content: [React Status](https://react.statuscode.com/) - Weekly React Summary - A weekly round-up of the latest React and React Native links and tutorials, always a good read. Tip: I sometimes find there's a lot to take in so I spread it out over 2 or 3 sittings.

data.title: React Docs
data.content: [React Docs](https://reactjs.org/docs/getting-started.html) - Read - The React docs serve as a solid starting point and a reference for all levels. I always find myself coming back and re-remembering the react hook syntax.

data.title: How to use React Context effectively
data.content: [How to use React Context effectively](https://kentcdodds.com/blog/how-to-use-react-context-effectively/) - Read/Bookmark - The legend that is Kent C Dodds shows us how to setup React context in a project. I always use this for my own context setup and it keeps everything nice and simple.

data.title: Building a custom React media query hook
data.content: [Building a custom React media query hook](https://www.netlify.com/blog/2020/12/05/building-a-custom-react-media-query-hook-for-more-responsive-apps/) - Read/Use - [@cassidoo](https://twitter.com/cassidoo) has written a deep dive on how we can use a custom hook to create a smart responsive experience in our React applications. I've been looking for a neat solution like this for a while without resorting to a package like [React Media](https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-media) so this ticks all the boxes.

data.title: A Guide to Jotai
data.content: [A Guide to Jotai](https://dmitripavlutin.com/react-jotai-state-management/) - Read - Dmitri Pavlutin gives a good overview of [Jotai](https://github.com/pmndrs/jotai) and how it can be used. [Jotai](https://github.com/pmndrs/jotai) best practices are still a little unknown but for me Dmitri has made some sensible decisions.

data.title: Visual Studio Code
data.content: [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/) - Firm Favourite - My go to editor of choice. No need for anymore suggestions, it's just that good. I'll also add some of my current config below.

data.title: Vite
data.content: [Vite](https://vitejs.dev/) - No Bundler/Lightening Fast - Leveraging ESM modules Vite is incredibly fast to startup, super flexible (doesn't tie you into a framework) and is an all round pleasure to work with. Run `npm init vite@latest` to get started.

data.title: Node Version Manager (NVM)
data.content: [Node Version Manager (NVM)](https://github.com/creationix/nvm) - A must have - Seamlessly manage your node and NPM versions. This has been a life saver on more than one occasion and it makes it all super simple. I have some snippets available which will help you in setting up and not having to scour the docs for relevant commands.

data.title: Gulp
data.content: [Gulp](https://gulpjs.com/) - Automate Tasks - A simple, easy to learn task runner, producing efficient builds, automate task. It will pretty much do whatever you want, has a huge ecosystem and is my go-to for WordPress development.

data.title: Carbon.now.sh
data.content: [Carbon](https://carbon.now.sh/) - Share Code Images - Create and share beautiful images of your source code. Images can easily be shared to twitter or you can download the images files and share that way.

data.title: Untools
data.content: [Untools](https://untools.co/) - Thinking/Learning - A collection of thinking tools and frameworks to help you solve problems, make decisions and understand systems. I've not read a lot of it yet but it seems pretty cool.

data.title: Raycast
data.content: [Raycast](https://raycast.com/) - Spotlight but better - I came across Raycast via a [tweet from @mxstbr](https://twitter.com/mxstbr/status/1395274968703832064) and I've got to say it's pretty amazing and improved my productivity and overall workflow tremendously. Quick Links is an amazing feature and I can open code projects quicker than ever!

data.title: Rectangle
data.content: [Rectangle](https://rectangleapp.com/) - Spectacle but better - Moving to a widescreen monitor meant I needed to focus a lot more on my window management. Being written in Swift means it's super quick and you can tweak all of the shortcuts to match your own preferences.

data.title: Wormhole
data.content: [Wormhole](https://code.visualstudio.com/) - Share files flawlessly - I like to think of it as weTransfer without the fuss. Forget waiting files to finish uploading to send out the link, share it straight away and let friends/colleagues start downloading simultaneously.

data.title: Snapdrop
data.content: [Snapdrop](https://snapdrop.net/) - Airdrop alternative - Sometimes I find airdrop to be a little temperamental so this neat little site lets you share files between devices if you are on the same network.

data.title: Setups.co
data.content: [Setups.co](https://setups.co/) - Creator Setup Inspiration - Feel your work setup is lacking? [setups.co](https://setups.co/) will give you all the aesthetic feels to get you pumped. Also great to scope out what tools creatives in the industry are using.

data.title: Deploying a PlanetScale, Next.js & Prisma App to Vercel
data.content: [Deploying a PlanetScale, Next.js & Prisma App to Vercel](https://davidparks.dev/blog/planetscale-deployment-with-prisma/) - Read/Bookmark - A great introduction to Planetscale and how to get up and running. This tutorial focuses on getting set up with Next but you can just as easily get set up for another framework (like this one, which is built with Remix)

data.title: Prisma
data.content:
[Prisma](https://www.prisma.io/) - Database ORM - By far the easiest way to interact with your database. The docs are great, the API is easy to learn and first-class Typescript support makes creating and using models a breeze. 

Some tips for Prisma:
* Install the [VS Code extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Prisma.prisma)
* Use `npx prisma studio` to visualise your data and make any manual changes.

data.title: Upstash
data.content: [Upstash](https://upstash.com/) - key/value store - Improve your back-end's performance by caching API responses in an Upstash Redis store. I use Upstash on this site and if you're shipping serverless I recommend using their REST API and creating your own get, set and delete methods.

data.title: Agney
data.content: [Agney](https://buttondown.email/agney) - Monthly gems - Agney does a terrific job of sharing interesting articles, tutorials and thought provoking Twitter threads. I always learn something new from each newsletter he drops.

data.title: User Interface Gallery
data.content: [User Interface Gallery](https://ui.gallery/) - Experimental UI's - A great project from [Rauno Freiberg](https://rauno.me/) ([@raunofreiberg](https://twitter.com/raunofreiberg)). Some really interesting ideas for UI design here and a refreshing take on common elements developers will be accustomed to creating.

data.title: Rauno Freiberg
data.content: [Rauno Freiberg](https://rauno.me/) - Playful UI elements - Rauno has a real gift for creating beautiful interfaces and playful interactive elements. One thing I gravitated towards was how smooth the navigation animation is between page transitions and how you get that "native" feel.

data.title: Fontshare
data.content: [Fontshare](https://www.fontshare.com/?fs=60&vt=grid) - Free Quality Fonts - Launched by the Indian Type Foundry, the creator of several popular source fonts (including [Poppins](https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Poppins), [Rajdhani](https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Rajdhani) and [Hind](https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Hind)), [Fontshare](https://www.fontshare.com/?fs=60&vt=grid) aims to help brands and individuals who don't have the budget, but want access to beautiful typography. They've done a stellar job and it's well worth checking out for your next project.

data.title: Open Foundry
data.content: [Open Foundry](https://open-foundry.com/fonts) - Open Source Fonts - The Open Foundry brings together a curated selection of some of the best open source fonts out there. If you're looking for some more stylised fonts, I recommend taking a look here.

data.title: DMCG (David McGillivray)
data.content: [David McGillivray](https://www.dmcg.co/) - Creative Director and Designer - I've followed David on Twitter for a while and rediscovered his work whilst scrolling [Lovers Magazine](https://www.loversmagazine.com/). His site is a real masterclass into how to sell yourself and presenting your projects. (he does unfortunately need to sort out his SSL certificate though... oops!)

data.title: Uncut.wtf
data.content: [Uncut.wtf](https://uncut.wtf/) - Libre Typeface Catalogue - A gem of a find found in this [thread](https://twitter.com/jamesm/status/1514360741570166785). It's more of a curator of links rather than an open source foundry itself, but what it does do is display the fonts in such a way that you get a great feel for them.

data.title: Collletttivo.it
data.content: [Collletttivo.it](http://collletttivo.it/) - Designed and Distributed - A smaller library of fonts than the others but hugely diverse in styles. Personally I see some fonts here that would make for a great large heading font or intro paragraph to your portfolio.

data.title: The Brand Identity
data.content: [The Brand Identity](https://the-brandidentity.com) - Graphic Inspiration - An independent graphic design resource with a global reach, showcasing the best projects, companies and products relevant to the industry.
